MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Textile Workers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the steps that are being taken in his Department for retraining and the provision of alternative employment for redundant textile workers in the Blarney area, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. M. O'Leary) Michael O'Leary
Speaker.P: The National Manpower Service have been interviewing the workers to be made redundant with a view to seeking to place them in other employment or arranging for retraining by AnCO for those who so wish.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Would the Minister say how many redundant workers there are, or there will be, and how many have been interviewed by Manpower and would he also indicate what alternative opportunities are likely to be available for them in the Blarney or Cork area in the foreseeable future?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I understand a replacement officer has been interviewing workers over recent weeks in an effort to inform them of any suitable or alternative employment that may become available. There is a prospect that the hosiery section will be restarted apart from Martin Mahoney and something like 45 workers could be reabsorbed there. There is also Irish Polysacs, established in Blarney last December. They will build up their work force from 45 to about 114 later this year and this should afford some outlet for redundant workers. We are, of course, endeavouring to expand the training facilities in Cork city and I think the entire work force of the factory amounted in all to 250.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The figure of 250 mentioned by the Minister is on the conservative side. Could I ask him whether he expects the remainder who are anxious to be employed will be able to get work in the foreseeable future? Would he ask his Government to show some concern for an area so long dependent on this industry and not just let it die and the area continue to experience what it is experiencing at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The Deputy knows the ills of the textile industry did not commence today or yesterday and the Deputy is aware of reports which pointed to the difficulties the industry is presently undergoing which were available to both management and the unions as far as the early sixties. The Deputy will concede, on the figures I have given, that there is within the foreseeable future very reasonable prospects of employment for 100 workers in the immediate area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give a guarantee he will take a personal interest in the provision of employment for the 40 odd people who were engaged in hosiery and in an expansion of employment in Irish Polysacs and will he use his influence to ensure as many as possible of the redundant workers will be absorbed there? Would he also impress on his colleague, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the necessity for keeping the hosiery industry going, even on a smaller scale?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: This is a Government that does not work very much on influence. Apart from the figures I have given the Deputy, the National Manpower Service and placement officers will continue their work of obtaining suitable employment for the employees. I have given two instances in which there are immediate prospects of employment. For those who cannot be absorbed practical training in the Cork area will be extended. The textile industry has been a problem throughout Europe and the difficulties in the industry have been common knowledge throughout the Irish industry for the last 20 years.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 7.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Just one final supplementary. Could the Minister indicate to me, so that I can tell the people in Blarney, what it is the Government work by because in the opinion of the people there and in my opinion the people have been ignored by the Government in their efforts to find employment?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is broadening the scope of the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: It is very important.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have given the Deputy a great deal of latitude. I am calling the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Government are letting Blarney die.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy allow questions to continue?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Will the Minister and his colleagues accept that this is a vital area?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Deputy please allow questions to continue?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I can tell the Minister snide remarks will not help these people to get bread and butter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carter Mr. Carter Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: and Mr. Carter asked the Minister for Labour the steps his Department are taking to provide for the retraining and re-employment of the redundant textile workers in Athlone, County Westmeath.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The National Manpower Service have been interviewing the workers concerned with a view to seeking to place them in other employment or, if they so wish, arranging for retraining by AnCO. I understand, however, that efforts to keep some operations going in this factory are still continuing.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - AnCO Programmes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cronin Mr. Cronin
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is satisfied that recent measures to shorten AnCO courses with a consequent increase in the number of trained persons becoming available for employment will not have the effect of flooding particular labour markets thereby causing disappointment to many young trainees; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: At my direction AnCO are making arrangements to increase the number of trainees they will cater for in 1973. About 7,000, including apprentices, will be trained in 1975 as against 4,500 in 1974. The funds available to AnCO in 1975 for retraining are expected to amount to £9.0 million against £4.6 million in the nine months to December, 1974. As part of the measures to increase the intake of trainees certain courses have been shortened in duration.

In my view industrial training is a valuable instrument of manpower policy which should be used as intensively as possible in times of high unemployment. The aim is to give the workers concerned additional skills which will enable them to benefit from the employment opportunities arising when the economy starts to recover from the recession. Even if expansion of training leads to some short-term disimprovement in the placement of trainees in employment, the policy is justified by the longer term benefits for the workers trained and for the economy generally.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Would the Minister impress upon his colleague, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, that many of these trainees could be taken up in employment if the Minister for Industry and Commerce utilised the provisions of the anti-dumping Act and prevented the wholesale dumping of textiles and other commodities?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, that matter has had the constant attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce. As the Deputy is also aware, there are certain international obligations which were entered into both by his Government and this Government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: There is no international law which prevents this company from using the country as a wholesale dumping ground. Other countries are presumably bound——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is now imparting information, not seeking it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: ——by whatever regulations they have and they are taking the measures I am now advocating.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Appreciating the need for training and retraining, is the Minister concerned at this stage about the opportunities that will be available for apprentices at the end of these AnCO courses?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The Deputy can be absolutely satisfied that this situation, in which we have growing unemployment, continues to be our concern and we will continue in our general budgetary policy to correct the situation. This relates to questions previously asked in the House and which no doubt will be asked again. As the Deputy knows, a great deal of our present malaise in the economy is caused by factors beyond our control. This does not minimise the hardships involved for those who suffer unemployment, but this hardship on their part is shared by many thousands throughout every country of the European Community. The Deputy was anxious to have information on this. It does not get away from the fact that in general our policy continues to maintain training at the highest pitch possible, to train as many as possible and our investment in this area, as I indicated already, is the highest ever. I think this is the correct policy even if certain people, because of the recession, do not immediately find jobs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: While I accept that situation entirely and also support the Minister's efforts at EEC level to get high priority treatment for the unemployment situation here——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Ask a question, Deputy, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Obviously we will have a number of apprentices and a number of trained people who in the short term will find it very difficult to get employment. Could the Minister not ask his colleagues to provide within their departments temporary employment on valuable projects that can be done at the present time and which the country needs?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is extending this question into another area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The Government have been reviewing in recent weeks all manner of short term injections into our economy, and this certainly has a high priority in our attention at the present time.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Question No. 9.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Can we be hopeful about the situation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the number of persons being retrained by AnCO in Dublin at present in each of the various skills for which training is given.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The total number of adult persons being retrained by AnCO in Dublin at present is 455. In addition, AnCO are training 162 apprentices in the Dublin area.

With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to circulate in the Official Report a statement detailing the various skills for which adult training is being given. The following is the statement:

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the amount of EEC funds available this year to aid the AnCO programmes; and whether any increase is expected.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The amount of assistance from the European Social Fund applied for by AnCO in respect of its 1975 operations was just over £5 million. The bulk of the AnCO application, involving £4.2 million was recommended for approval in full by the advisory committee of the fund at its March meeting. It is understood that it has now been approved by the European Commission, though formal notification is awaited.

The remainder of the AnCO 1975 application will be considered by the fund committee at its June meeting and should be decided by the Commission shortly afterwards. It is not possible to say at this stage what the Commission's decision will be.
The total amount applied for by AnCO in respect of 1975 is more than twice as much as the amount approved for 1974 and three times that approved for 1973.

Two further grants from EEC sources have been approved towards the costs of pilot schemes being undertaken by AnCO, one from the social fund amounting to £12,510, of which £6,255 has been paid in 1975, and the second from the EEC Directorate for Regional Affairs for £10,000, of which £4,000 has been paid.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Could the Minister say, in respect of the applications for the 1975 allocation, if that will be spent in the same way as for the 1974 allocation, which I understand was used in toto for vocational training? Is it proposed to use the 1975 allocation, if received, for the same purpose or has any new aspect been brought into consideration?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Our main objective has been to absorb as many of the newly unemployed as possible in training programmes, that is attempting to use the training resources available to us from the social fund to mop up as many of our unemployed as possible. This has been our general approach.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is there a suggested change in the allocation of the social fund? Is there a fear that this change may be to our disadvantage?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: No. It is another question. What the Deputy probably has in mind is that at our council meeting later this month I will be attempting to see how funds can be diverted towards the young unemployed, those unemployed who had no previous work experience and whom the regulation of the fund would presently debar from participating in any training programme. We are seeing how we can remove this regulation. I hope to get the co-operation of my colleagues at our June 17th meeting to see if this can be done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is it true to say that money over and above the allocation can be got from the fund?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Not really.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It is. The Chair decides so. The question refers to the amount of the fund and any increase that might likely arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I accept your ruling. I will put down a separate question because it is a matter of national importance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: What amount of this fund will be detailed towards the retraining of the car workers who have recently been affected by redundancy?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: They will have the same proportion of participation in this fund as any other group of unemployed workers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Would special consideration not be given to the car workers?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: As I said our priority has been help towards the newly unemployed. They will come under that category.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Are they not in a special category?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I do not know of any more special category than immediate treatment to their case. They are the newly unemployed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Surely the Minister will agree that the car workers have been more seriously affected than anybody else.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Any worker who is unemployed is affected in some way.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: They are particularly affected because of the savage increase in the cost of petrol last year.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Labour Court Negotiating Machinery.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will consider restructuring the Labour Court and its conciliation and arbitration services on a regional basis in an effort to expedite and provide a greater local knowledge for its negotiating machinery.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I have completed a review of our industrial relations structures including that of the Labour Court and its Conciliation Service and I intend introducing amending legislation in due course. The proposals will include a provision to appoint at least one extra division of the Labour Court.

Under existing arrangements, individual industrial relations officers are allocated to provincial as well as Dublin areas, travelling where necessary to hold conciliation conferences. Under this system the personnel of the service maintain close contact with union officials and personnel officers in all parts of the country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Does the Minister consider that a regional base in a southern or a western area with more local contact would not in fact be a help? As he is aware one of the problems in a local area particularly is break-down in communications and special difficulties experienced. Would he not agree that a more knowledgeable approach on a local basis would assist in industrial relations through the machinery of the Labour Court?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The direction we should take is that the industrial relations officer should be well acquainted with a sector of industry or a particular service. If the Deputy is referring to that kind of knowledge that is essential, and it is not necessary that that is gained in a regional context, it could be equally claimed that too much regional or local connection might disqualify an industrial relations officer from being so effective. It is an Irish trait, as the Deputy knows, not to have much faith in the local man.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is the Minister saying that his idea in the restructuring might be on categorising of particular industries under one umbrella?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - European Vocational Training Centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the action the Government is taking with regard to the EEC Regulation on the creation of a European vocational training centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The Council of Ministers of the European Communities meeting on 17th December, 1974, agreed in principle to the Regulation establishing the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.
The regulation was formally adopted by a Council meeting on 10th February, 1975, and it was decided to locate the centre in West Berlin.

The centre will be administered by a management board comprising 30 members. Of these 30 members, nine will represent the governments of the member states, nine the employers' organisations, nine the trade unions and three the commission.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Industrial Liaison Officers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour why it was considered necessary to readvertise the positions of industrial liaison officers in his Department on 14th May, 1975; and if he will outline the changes from the previous advertisement and the reason for them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The success of the work of industrial liaison officers appointed in my Department to maintain contact with major developments in key sections will to a large extent depend on the quality of the personnel selected.

Certain applicants might have been reluctant to reply in view of objections which the staff association had expressed on the establishment of the unit. Following the resolution of these objections, I felt it would be desirable to readvertise the posts and thereby extend the closing date so that persons interested in the posts might have a reasonable opportunity of submitting applications.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: There is one part of the question which I do not think the Minister answered, that is the changes from the first advertisement to the second one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Yes, that is true. From my knowledge of the advertisement I think the only change was that the period of service required for the prospective officers was cut from eight to five years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not accept that the reason for the second advertisement was a breakdown in negotiations or consultations?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: There was a labour dispute.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: What kind of labour dispute? Was there not a breakdown in communications from the month of March until such time as an emergency situation arose in the country?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that there was the possibility of many applicants who might be interested in this post not applying when there was full public knowledge reported in the press that there was a dispute situation in my Department. It was obvious again that, if I wished to have the possibility of obtaining the most suitable applicants, there should be a fresh advertisement when the threat of a strike was lifted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I accept that fully, but would the Minister not now accept that if consultations had been held with the staff in time before the first advertisement was inserted the country would have been saved the added expense of a second advertisement?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy not know that when a dispute is settled there is no point in going into the history and the background of it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is it not true that if——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: History is full of ifs.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The dispute is not involved in this question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Irish-based Security Companies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he has taken steps to ensure that all semi-State bodies under his control will give preference to Irish-based security companies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: One of the State-sponsored bodies with which I am concerned engages the services of four companies for security work at their different premises. Contracts for the services are placed annually following tender. All four companies involved were Irish but one of them has become a branch of an international company.
I have asked the State-sponsored body involved to review the situation and they are doing so.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Female Workers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if it is proposed to change the laws or regulations prohibiting female workers from working night shifts; and, if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: My statutory responsibility in this matter arises from the Conditions of Employment Act, 1936, which prohibits the employment of women on industrial work between the hours of 10 p.m. and 8 a.m.

MainHeading.P: In addition, Ireland has ratified the relevant Convention of the International Labour Organisation concerning night work by women employed in industry. The situation is being reviewed, but I am not in a position at present to say what, if any, changes I might propose.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: Does “industrial work” by definition in the Act include workers in the Post Office?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: It does.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: And the Minister does not know when this will be done?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: As I say, it is under review at present, and in any changes of this sort I would have to consult with the unions and with the employers, certainly with the unions in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that there is a wish on the part of many of the female staff in our telephone exchanges to have at least available to them equal facilities for earning equal money for equal work?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I am so aware.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Minister referred to consultations with the unions. Could I ask him if such consultations have not already taken place?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: We have given a direction that consultations should be carried out, but I am not in a position to say whether they have started yet.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Youth Training.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the steps being taken by his Department to provide training for the youth of the country who cannot find even part-time employment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: About 2,000 youths are being trained at present by AnCO and CERT, the majority of them on craft courses. In addition, CERT have trained 750 young people this year for seasonal employment in the hotel and catering industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: As we are facing a rather unusual situation this year in relation to the employment of these young people, would the Minister consider getting together with his colleague, the Minister for Education, AnCO and the teachers' organisation to provide a two-month educational course for these young people for which they would be given some payment? Unless we take some serious action and show that we do care and want to do something for them we may pay for it very dearly afterwards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Already we have been holding short courses around the country to provide what we refer to as inductions to industry courses, but I agree this is not a sufficient response to the situation with which the Deputy is concerned. At present the training facilities, which is my direct responsibility, are not open to those who have had no previous work experience. We are attempting to change those regulations so that people who in the present recession have not had the opportunity of having a job can enjoy the training facilities which other workers enjoy at present. Though our response has not been totally adequate to the serious problem before us, I think it is only fair to say that we are spending more money on training than we have ever spent before. The officials in my Department both at European level and here at home are continuing their efforts to see how young people, in particular, can be helped at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: The Minister said we are spending more money on training than ever before, which is quite true. We are also spending more money on food than ever before but we are not getting more food. It is the same with employment.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: A question Deputy, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore
Speaker.P: Would the Minister try to do something this year for these young people?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I know the Deputy's exhortations are sincerely meant, but it is a problem that concerns me very much indeed. We shall continue all efforts to see how, within existing regulations, we can get both the assistance of the European Social Fund and of local Exchequer resources in order to provide worthwhile training for young people so that they can begin their working careers with some level of skill once international conditions pick up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: In view of statements made in this House and articles written in the newspapers, is the Minister satisfied that we are getting all we are entitled to under the European Social Fund, or is there some part of that fund that we can now avail of?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: While it is a separate question, a Cheann Comhairle, I can reassure the Deputy to this extent that it is believed by the Industrial Development Authority, which is the agency principally concerned here, that the 1969 Industrial Development Act, which is admittedly narrower in scope than the provisions of the European Social Fund—which permits of facilities of cash going for depreciation purposes —provides arrangements which give the utmost benefit to the Irish economy in our situation. That continues to be their view, but it is a separate question, and if the Deputy puts down a question on it at another time, we can come back to it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Is it true to say that moneys could be available to us, say, for Bord na Móna development——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is a distinct and separate matter and must be raised at another time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I am not trying to brush the Deputy's questions aside, but they involve such questions as IDA allowances for depreciation, so that it would be impossible to give a yes or no answer as sought by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I shall put down another question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Deontais Tithíochta.
MainHeading.P: 17. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé beartaithe aige ardú réasúnach a dhéanamh ar na deontais tithíochta.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Gaeltacht (Mr. O'Donnell) Thomas G. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ardaíodh na deontais sin cúpla bliain ó shin i Mí Feabhra, 1973, agus níl i gceist iad a mhéadú arís ag an bpointe seo.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire go bhfuil an deontas faoi láthair magúil mar go bhfuil an deontas mar sin le ceithre bliana anuas agus nár tháinig aon ardú air, in ainneoin gur tháinig ardú an-mhór ar ábhair do thithe i rith an ama sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tuigim sin, ach níl aon eolas agam go bhfuil mi-shásamh ar mhuintir na Gaeltachta maidir le méid an deontais. Admhaím go bhfuil a lán mí-shásaimh maidir le coinníollacha na scéime tithíochta.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Faoi mar adúras admhaím go bhfuil mishástacht ann mar gheall ar na coinnióllacha ach mar adúras, ní bhfuair mé gearáin ó aon duine ar fud na Gaeltachta maidir le méid an deontais ach fuair mé a lan gearán maidir le coinníollacha na scéime. Gach lá bíonn siad ag teacht isteach chuig mo Roinnse. Níl sé i gceist ag an bpointe seo méid an deontais a ardú.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Má tá gearáin de dhíth ar an Aire déanaim an gearán seo dó anois thar ceann a lán daoine ins na Gaeltachtaí go raibh mé ag caint leo le roint ama anuas.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: Is ait liom go gceapann an tAire nach bhfuil an gearán seo ag muintir na Gaeltachta agus tugaimsa, freisin, cuireadh dhó teacht go dtí mo Ghaeltacht féin go háirithe, Gaeltacht Chonamara go bhfeicidh sé na buachaillí agus na cailíní óga atá pósta faoi láthair agus atá ag iarraidh teach nua a thógaint chun fanúint sa Ghaeltacht agus nach bhfuil sin ar a n-acmhainn de bhrí go bhfuil an deontas chomh magúil agus atá sé.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: D'fhreagair mé an cheist.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Caithimid dul ar aghaidh.

MainHeading.P: 18. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad airgid a íocadh amach ar dheontais tithíochta i nGaeltacht Chonamara (a) i 1973 (b) i 1974 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is iad na suimeanna a íocadh í gContae na Gaillimhe ná (a) £111,229, (b) £139,075 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975 £20,273.

MainHeading.P: 19. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad airgid a íocadh amach i ndeontais tithíochta i nGaeltacht Chorcaí (a) i 1973 (b) i 1974 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is iad na suimeanna a íocadh i gContae Chorcaí ná (a) £15,988, (b) £17,732 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975 £3,045.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An n-abróidh an tAire os na figiúirí seo sa chéad cheathrú den bhliain seo, £3,000, gur comhartha é sin go bhfuil laghdú ag teacht ar thógáil tithe sa Ghaeltacht agus go gcruthaíonn sé sin go bhfuil gá le hardú deontas?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ní shílim go bhfuil an ceart ag an Teachta mar baineann na figiúirí sin leis an chéad cheathrú de 1975 agus, de ghná, ní hé sin an tréimhse ina mbíonn tithe á dthógáil. Baineann sé leis an ngeimhreadh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An n-admhaíonn an tAire, ag féachaint ar na figiúirí do 1973 agus 1974 go bhfuil ardú de £2,000 tagtha ar an méad airgid a caitheadh ar thithíocht, ar dheontais agus de bhrí go bhfuil ardú níos mó faoin gcéad tagtha ar na hábhair tógála nach gcruthaíonn sé sin chomh maith go bhfuil níos lú airgid á chaitheamh ar thithíocht agus gur gá rud éigean a dhéanamh chun níos mó tithe a sholáthar?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ní aontaím leis an Teachta mar, dáiríre, níl a fhios agam an bhfuil an ceart aige nó nach bhfuil ach mar a fheicimse an scéal tá méadú ann gach bliain.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Ar aghaidh linn go dtí Ceist a 20.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tá na hiarratais ag teacht isteach fós.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tionscail Ghaeltachta.
MainHeading.P: 20. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé beartaithe aige aon mhonarcha nua bhreise a chur ar fáil i nGaeltacht Chonamara sa todhchaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Bíonn idirbheartaíocht ar siúl i gcónaí ag Gaeltarra Éireann d'fhonn tionscail bhreise a bhunú agus, aon uaír a bheidh monarcha nua ag teastáil, cuirfear ar fáil í. Tá réamhmhonarchana á dtógáil ar an gCeathrú Rua agus i gCorr na Móna, tá monarcha do thionscal nua á tógáil i Ros an Mhíl, tá foirgnimh eile le tógáil go luath i gCarna agus ar an gCeathrú Rua agus tá monarcha beartaithe do Thír an Fhia.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An féidir leis an Aire a rá an mbeidh mórán fostaíochta ins na monarchana seo a luaigh sé?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ba mhaith liom mo leithscéal a ghabháil ach níl aon eolas agamsa ag an bpointe seo ach amháin liosta na monarchana. Má chuireann an Teachta ceist eile síos, freagróidh mé í.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An bhfuil an tAire ag rá mar sin go bhfuil na réamh-mhonarchana tosnaithe faoi láthair nó le tosnú?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tá réamhmhonarcha á tógáil ar an gCeathrú Rua faoi láthair agus i gCorr na Móna. Chomh maith leis sin, tá monarcha do thionscal nua á tógáil i Ros an Mhíl agus tá foirgnimh eile le tógáil go luath i gCarna agus ar an gCeathrú Rua agus tá tionscail eile beartaithe chomh maith.

Speaker.hpid: Ruairí Brugha Ruairí Brugha
Speaker.P: Maidir leis na monarchana agus leis na foirgnimh a luaigh an tAire, an féidir leis a rá go bhfuil conradh cinnte déanta le lucht bainistíochta chun na monarchana seo a chur ag obair nó an bhfuil Gaeltarra ag tógáil monarchana gan aon chonradh?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: D'fhreagair mé an cheist a bhí thíos.

MainHeading.P: 21. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad daoine a bhí fostaithe sna monarchana éagsúla i nGaeltacht Mhúscraí, Contae Chorcaí ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1974 agus ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1975.

MainHeading.P: 22. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad daoine a bhí fostaithe i nGaeltachtaí Mhaigh Eo sna monarchana éagsúla ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1974, agus ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1975.

MainHeading.P: 23. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad daoine a bhí fostaithe i nGaeltacht Chonamara sna monarchana éagsúla ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1974 agus ar an 2ú lá de Bhealtaine, 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Le chead an Cheann Comhairle, tógfaidh mé Ceisteanna 21, 22 agus 23 le chéile.

Glacaim agam gurb iad na tionscail a bhfuil baint ag Gaeltarra Éireann leo atá i gceist—tionscail Ghaeltarra féin, comhthionscail ina bhfuil scaireanna ag Gaeltarra agus miontionscadail a fuair cabhair ó Ghaeltarra. Níl figiúirí fostaíochta ar fáil don 2 Bealtaine: is amhlaidh nach mhailítear na figiúirí sin ach do thús agus lár na bliana féilire. Tá tábla agam a thugann an t-eolas a fuarthas ó Ghaeltarra do lár 1974 agus do thús 1975 agus, le chead an Cheann Comhairle, cuirfear timpeall sa Tuairisc Oifigiúil é.

MainHeading.P: Seo a leanas an tábla:—
(a) Áirítear daoine (i) a bhfuil obair shéasúrach acu in óstáin agus (ii) a bhí ag obair i miontionscadail sular chabhraigh Gaeltarra leo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An féidir leis an Aire an meamram a chuir Gaeltarra Éireann amach le déanaí, na figiúirí don bhliain 1974, a thabhairt? Tá siad i gcló.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tá fadhb anseo toisc nach mbeidh na figiúirí don tréimhse seo ar fáil go ceann cúpla seachtain.

MainHeading.P: 24. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad monarchana nua a tógadh i nGaeltacht Chonamara (a) i 1973 (b) i 1974 agus (c) sa chéad ráithe de 1975; agus cén bhliain ar socraíodh na monarchana sin a thógáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is mar seo a leanas a críochnaíodh monarchana nua i nGaeltacht na Gaillimhe:—(a) ceithre cinn i 1973 ar ceadaíodh iad i 1972; (b) cúig cinn i 1974 ar ceadaíodh ceann amháin díobh i 1972, dhá cheann i 1973 agus dhá cheann i 1974; agus (c) níor críochnaíodh aon mhonarcha sa chéad ráithe de 1975 ach bhí dhá cheann á dtógáil ar ceadaíodh ceann amháin díobh i 1972 agus an ceann eile i 1974. Sa tréimhse ón chéad lá d'Aibreán 1973 go dtí seo ceadaíodh deontais do caoga mion-tionscal chomh maith i nGaeltacht na Gaillimhe.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An féidir leis an Aire a insint dhúinn cé mhéad de na monarchana seo atá ar oscailt faoi láthair agus cé mhéad go bhfuil lán-fhostaíocht iontu?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ceadaíodh iad go léir i 1972——

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: Go raibh maith agat, a Aire, ar son an eolais sin ach is í in cheist a chuir mé ná cé mhéad de na monarchana seo atá críochnaithe faoi láthair agus a bhfuil lán-fhostaíocht iontu?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Níl an t-eolas sin agam.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: Ón dteagmháil atá ag an Aire leis na Gaeltachtaí agus le cúrsaí Gaeltachta, an bhfuil sé ag rá anois nach bhfuil aon eolas aige cé acu tá monarchana a tógadh le dhá bhliain, nó le trí bhliain anuas ag obair nó nach bhfuil? Má tá an t-eolas ag an Aire, ba cheart dó é a thabhairt ag éirí as an bhfo-cheist seo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Mar adúras, ní raibh an t-eolas sin ag teastáil. Sí an cheist a bhí ann ná cé mhéad monarchana nua a tógadh.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: Nach gnáth an t-eolas seo a bheith ag Aire nuair a bhíonn sé ag freagairt ceiste? D'iarrfainn ar an Aire nuair a cuirtear síos ceist arís go mbeadh an t-eolas aige.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Níl an iomad sin monarcha sa Ghaeltacht ar fad agus bíonn an tAire de réir na bpáipéirí, ag bogadaigh thart sa Ghaeltacht——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Ceist ghairid le do thoil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An bhfuil a fhios ag an Aire go bhfuil monarcha amháin, nó dhá cheann díobh seo nach bhfuil ag obair go fóill agus na cinn atá ag obair? Má tá an t-eolas sin aige is ceart dó an t-eolas sin a thabhairt don Teachta Geoghegan-Quinn. Is bliain na mban í seo agus ba cheart don Aire a bheith——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Gheobhaidh mé an t-eolas sin amach ach is é mo thuairimse nach monarcha atá i gceist ag an Teachta ach tionscalaíocht.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Deontais Feabhsúcháin Bóithre.
MainHeading.P: 25. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad airgid a íocadh amach i ndeontais fheabhsúcháin bóithre i nGaeltacht Chorcaí (a) i 1973 (b) i 1974 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Íocadh £3,470 do Ghaeltacht Chorcaí i 1974 agus ní bhfuarthas aon iarratas ón gcomhairle chontae ar íocaíocht i 1973 ná sa chéad ráithe de 1975.

MainHeading.P: 26. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéad airgid a íocadh amach i ndeontais fheabhsúcháin bóithre i nGaeltacht Chonamara (a) i 1973 (b) i 1974 agus (c) sa chéad cheathrú de 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is iad na suimeanna a íocadh do Ghaeltacht na Gaillimhe ná £42,290 i 1973 agus £82,580 i 1974. Ní bhfuarthas aon iarratas ón gcomhairle chontae ar íocaíocht sa chéad ráithe de 1975.

MainHeading.P: 27. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.NameTxt: Mr. Cunningham, Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn, Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: agus Mr. Gallagher d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil deontais ar fáil faoi láthair le feabhas a chur ar bhóithre i gceantair Ghaeltachta; agus an bhfuil sé i gceist aige leanúint leis na deontais sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tá deontais mar sin ar fáil agus tá i gceist agam leanúint leo.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Téacsleabhair agus Nuachtáin Ghaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 28. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: agus Mr. Meaney d'Aire na Gaeltachta an eol dó go bhfuil gá mór le (a) leabhair bhunscoile (b) téacsleabhair iar-bhunoideachais agus (c) nuachtáin Ghaeilge do mhuintir na Gaeltachta; agus an bhfuil aon scéim chabhraithe aige ina gcóir sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Chun freastal ar lucht léite agus lucht scríofa na Gaeilge sa Ghaeltacht agus sa chuid eile den tír tá cúnamh airgid á thabhairt agam do cheithre cinn d'irisí áitiúla Gaeltachta, don dá nuachtán sheachtainiúla i nGaeilge agus do thréimhseacháin eile.

MainHeading.P: Ní ormsa atá an phríomhfhreagracht i leabhair ná téacsleabhair scoile don Ghaeltacht ach bím i síorchomhairle leis an Aire Oideachais i dtaobh gach gné den oideachas sa Ghaeltacht.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: Ba cheart don Aire dul i gcomhairle lena chomrádaí. An bhfuil a fhios aige nach bhfuil dóthain téacsleabhar i nGaeilge ag muintir na Gaeltachta?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is é sin ceann de na céad fhadhbanna atá le cur á réiteach agus aontaím gur fadhb anmhór í ach tuigimse—ach níl an t-eolas agamsa anseo—go bhfuil idirbheartaíocht ar siúl faoi láthair chun comhlacht chlódóireachta nua a bhunú i nGaeltacht na Gaillimhe chun téacsleabhair agus nuachtáin Ghaeilge do mhuintir na Gaeltachta a chlóbhualadh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An bhfuil a fhios ag an Aire go bhfuil gá le téacsleabhair sna bunscoileanna chomh maith leis na h-iar-bhunscoileanna? An bhféadfadh sé a rá cén dul chun cinn atá déanta le cúpla bliain anuas le feabhas a chur ar an scéal sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An n-abróidh an tAire an chaint atá ar siúl chun foilsiúcháin a chur ar siúl sa Ghaeltacht? An mbeidh Gaeltarra Éireann istigh air sin? An mbeidh cáirde acu ann? An tionscal príobháideach a bhéas ann ar fad?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Más mian leis an Teachta ceist a chur síos i dtaobh an fhógra sin, cuirfidh mé an t-eolas ar fáil ach chomh fada agus a thuigimse an scéal beidh Gaeltarra Éireann páirteach ann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Cé hiad na daoine atá i mbun na gcainteanna seo mar gheall ar fhoilsiúcháin a chur ar fáil sa Ghaeltacht?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Is ceist thábhachtach í seo. Táimse chun fógra a thabhairt go bhfuil sé ar intinn agam an cheist seo a phlé ar Athló na Dála.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Raghaidh m'oifig i gcomhairle leis an Teachta.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ceantair Ghaeltachta.
MainHeading.P: 29. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett Mr. Barrett
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé i gceist aige an chuid thiar de Chontae an Chláir a ainmniú mar Ghaeltacht; agus, má tá, cé chomh luath a dhéanfar sin.

MainHeading.P: 30. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Meaney Mr. Meaney
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé i gceist aige leathnú a dhéanamh ar Ghaeltacht Mhúscraí, Contae Chorcaí; agus, má tá, an ndéanfaidh sé ráiteas ina thaobh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Le chead an Cheann Comhairle, tógfaidh mé Ceist a 29 agus Ceist a 30 le chéile.

Táimse sásta breithniú báúil a dhéanamh ar eolas sonrach faoi úsáid na Gaeilge mar ghnáthurlabhra a bheith á leathnú le blianta beaga anuas in aon cheantar agus, má léirítear dom gur Gaeilgeoirí mórchuid de na daoine ann, molfaidh mé don Rialtas an ceantar a áireamh sa Ghaeltacht. Tá an méid sin mínithe agam do dhaoine a rinne achainíocha liom i dtaobh ceantar Chill Bheathach i gContae an Chláir agus ceantar Chill na Martra i gContae Chorcaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Nár thug an tAire geallúint dhá bhliain ó shin go nglacfaí an ceantar seo agus ceantair eile isteach sa bhfíor-Ghaeltacht agus an bhfuil sé á rá anois go mbrathann sé go fóill ar choinníollacha áirithe atá i bhfeidhm? Cad mar gheall ar an ngeallúint a thug sé go deimhnitheach dhá bhliain ó shin go dtógfaí isteach iad?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Mar adúras sa bhfreagra, má léirítear domsa gur Gaeilgeoirí morchuid de na daoine in aon cheantar molfaidh mé don Rialtas an ceantar a áireamh sa Ghaeltacht.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Tá an tAire ag dul siar ar na geallúintí anois.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Seo mar adúirt mé leo. Dúirt mé i gcás Chorca Dhuibhne go molfainn don Rialtas ceantar Chlocháin Bréanainn a tharraingt isteach sa Ghaeltacht. Rinneadh é sin. Ina dhiaidh sin mhol mé don Rialtas go gcuirfear ceantar Seana Phobal i nGaeltacht na Rinne sa Ghaeltacht. Rinneadh é sin. Maidir leis an dá áit atá i gceist anseo, sé sin Cill Bheathach agus Cill na Martra, fuair mé achainíocht i dtaobh na gceantar sin; thug mé cuairt ar Chill Bheathach. Mhínigh mé an scéal go soiléir do na daoine go raibh coinníollacha ann agus go gcaithfeadh muintir na h-áite sin na coinníollacha a chomhlíonadh, sé sin, ní féidir aon áit d'aithint mar Ghaeltacht oifigiúil muna mbíonn an teanga mar ghnáthurlabhra ann. Má deintear iarracht i gCill Bheathach chun an teanga a chur chun cinn nuair a bheidh na daoine réidh cuirfidh mé cigire de mo Roinn amach chun an caighdeán Gaeilge a scrúdú ann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Tá a lán daoine so tír a chuala an tAire ag rá i gcás Cill na Martra i gContae Chorcaí go raibh deimhin-bheartú déanta aige an limistéir sin a thabhairt isteach sa Ghaeltacht.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Tá mé ag rá nár dhúirt mé go raibh aon rud beartaithe.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ùsáid Dheontais.
MainHeading.P: 31. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an dtabharfaidh sé mioneolas faoi úsáid an deontais £134,000 a fuair Gaeltarra Éireann ó Chiste Sóisialach CEE i gcás (a) scéimeanna ceard-oiliúna (b) na hionaid ina raibh na scéimeanna lonnaithe agus (c) an méad a caitheadh i ngach ionad.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Is amhlaidh a fhaigheann Gaeltarra Éireann leath an chaiteachais údaraithe do scéimeanna oiliúna as an gCiste sin Bíonn an oiliúint ar siúl ar fud na Gaeltachta—go hairithe i dtionscail nua. Tá tábla agam ina dtugtar roinnt mioneolais agus, le chead an Cheann Comhairle, cuirfear timpeall sa Tuairisc Oifigiúil é.
Seo a leanas an tábla:—

row.entry: Scéimeanna oil-iúna agus costais eile de chuid Ghaeltarra Éireann

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: An féidir leis an Aire a rá maidir le scéimeanna traenála, “vocational training”, scéimeanna traenála teicniciúla gairmoideachais, ar caitheadh an t-airgead go léir orthu sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Scéimeanna “vocational training”?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Gairmthraenáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: No, scéimeanna. Bíonn an oiliúint ar siúl ar fud na Gaeltachta, go h-áirithe i dtionscail nua.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cunningham Mr. Cunningham
Speaker.P: Níl an tAire ag freagairt na ceiste. Deir an ráiteas a cuireadh amach ó Ghaeltarra Éireann i gcóir na bliana 1974 gur caitheadh an t-airgead seo ar scéimeanna gairmthraenála ag Gaeltarra Éireann. Agus is í an cheist a chuir mé na hionaid ina raibh na scéimeanna lonnaithe, cé hiad na h-áiteanna inar caitheadh an t-airgead ar na scéimeanna gairmthraenála sin agus an méad airgid a caitheadh i ngach ionad. Níor thug an tAire eolas ar bith faoi sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Donnell Mr. O'Donnell

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Questions. - Veterinary Services Dispute.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries whether in view of the disastrous effects on employment and industry resulting from the absence of veterinary services in meat factories and abbatoirs, he will arrange immediately for the re-opening of negotiations with the Veterinary Union with an acceptable independent arbitrator; and, pending the outcome of such negotiations, he will ask that the veterinary services be restored.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the immediate steps he is taking in the present dispute affecting veterinary services to prevent loss of employment in meat factories.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: I propose with the permission of the Ceann Comhairle to take these two questions together.

The difficulties which have arisen derive from the refusal of the Irish Veterinary Union to agree to the introduction of trained lay personnel to take blood samples from cattle under the brucellosis eradication scheme.

My original proposal was to introduce lay personnel in all areas to which the scheme applied but, following prolonged discussions and in an endeavour to meet the union's viewpoint I decided to confine their introduction to the six north-western counties in which brucellosis has been eradicated but where control measures must of course, continue to apply. I have, therefore, already modified very substantially my original proposal, and the only further step open to me would be to withdraw my decision altogether. The union on the other hand have shown themselves unwilling to depart in any way from their original and adamant opposition to the introduction of lay blood samplers although such samplers have been operating in Northern Ireland and Britain for a number of years with the full agreement of the veterinary profession and the Royal Veterinary College.

There is an adequate number of veterinary officers on my Department's staff to service the meat factories so that farmers need not be inconvenienced or the meat trade disrupted during the period of the dispute. While the requisite staff have been instructed to report for duty at meat factories, some staff association problems have arisen. These problems will fall to be dealt with in the context of the Civil Service Regulations Acts and the conditions of employment of the officers concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that if the present problems are connected with the brucellosis scheme that was also the position at the beginning of April last when I asked him a parliamentary question alerting him as to the present position and he told me that he was not aware that there was any likelihood of there being unemployment arising out of it? The Minister would accept that on 10th April I tabled a similar question to him alerting him as to the position and he told me that as far as he was aware there was no danger to employment in abattoirs or factories. That was in connection with the slaughter premium scheme. What change has occurred since April to make him attribute everything to the brucellosis scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I feel that there is a misunderstanding and that Deputy Tunney is dealing with a separate matter altogether.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: That is the question I asked the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: The trouble in relation to the matter which Deputy Tunney has raised is that it is really a local authority matter. The inspections of meat in the normal way were carried out at these local abattoirs and slaughter houses by the local authority veterinary inspectors. In the normal way there was supposed to be ante-and post-mortem examination. I understand now from the developments that have taken place that ante inspection did not take place by the local authorities although that would be a normal thing for them to do, and the question arises. They then sought additional remuneration for doing this extra inspection but in my view at quite an unreasonable rate, for instance, £2 a head in Dublin county.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: Eighty pence in Dublin city.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: Eighty pence in Dublin city. There is this sort of discrepancy. I have told the butchers, the people concerned, that the slaughter premium will be paid. So, there should be no disruption.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: Is the Minister now telling me and the House that in respect of the administration of a scheme for which money is available to us from the EEC under FEOGA grants, it is the responsibility of the local authority and not the responsibility of the Department to administer that scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: Yes. If the local authorities were doing the inspection as it should be done there would be no necessity for an additional inspection and an additional expense.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: In the last few sentences of the Minister's reply was there a veiled threat to the employment of members of the Veterinary Association who are working in his Department? Would he be prepared at this stage to accept an independent mediator? Was he offered an independent mediator yesterday?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Was there no contact with his Department?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: Not that I am aware of.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept an independent mediator?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: No, not at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister prepared to let 4,000 or 5,000 people out of jobs because he is not prepared to settle the dispute? He is being sold by the civil servants and I am sorry for him.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must deal with this matter in an orderly fashion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: It is a very serious matter for employees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I was asked if there was an offer of a mediator and I said no. I have done nothing as of today——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: That is obvious.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: The practitioners have gone on strike because I have said that at a future date I intend to bring in lay samplers. No lay samplers have been brought in but the practitioners have withdrawn their services. If the Deputy wants to make representations he should make them to his veterinary contacts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Will the Minister not agree that proposals were put to his officials by the Veterinary Union last March and a copy was delivered to him but some of his officials were so indolent they would not accept it?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: There should not be a reflection cast on officials.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: The Minister has been continually talking about discussions but he has never negotiated with the union. He presented them with a fait accompli in May and, by that action, he has caused a strike that will escalate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I want to contradict emphatically what the Deputy has said. I spoke to the practitioners in 1973 and in 1974 and I had two meetings with them in 1975. They have had two additional meetings with officials of the Department. To say I had no discussion or negotiation is completely untrue and the Deputy knows that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Would the Minister be prepared——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must proceed with other business. I will allow a final supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: This is something that is affecting our economy——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: It affects the economy like every strike.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Every striker was not called irresponsible. The language of the Minister in this House last week was irresponsible——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is engaging in an argument.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Will the Minister accept a leader of any of the farming organisations who are affected as a mediator in this case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: There are normal and well-recognised developments in any strike situation. I will deal with this as it arises, not as dictated by Deputy Davern.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister denying that a person was offered by independent people——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We cannot debate this matter today. This is Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I deny what the Deputy has said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give consideration to them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I will consider any situation that arises in the course of this development.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: When will the Minister do that? Will he let this situation continue?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I will consider it when it is opportune to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that the strike will escalate?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must proceed to the next business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: The Minister will not be able to put in lay practitioners because they will not be trained. The Minister is not helping the economy at a vital time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Will the Minister tell us if it will be possible in any circumstances to complete the brucellosis eradication programme before 1978 without the assistance of lay staff? Is this not at the heart of the question? Will the Minister not agree that the real danger is that we may find ourselves in 1978 with the brucellosis eradication programme not finished and, as a consequence, we will be unable to export to the continent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: I am glad the Deputy has raised this matter because it is my serious concern that it will not be possible to eradicate the diseases within the limited time available.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I am calling the Capital Gains Tax Bill. Deputy Colley reported progress.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Will the Minister not agree he has not accepted the professional advice of the veterinary surgeons in his Department and that he has ignored the Veterinary Association? He has accepted the views of civil servants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Clinton Mr. Clinton
Speaker.P: The Deputy has made the most ridiculous statements.

MainHeading.Title: Capital Gains Tax Bill, 1974: Committee Stage (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Question again proposed: “That Schedule 3, as amended, be Schedule 3 of the Bill.”

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I was dealing with paragraph 8 (3) of Schedule 3 when we adjourned the debate. I pointed out to the Minister that it seemed to contain a most extraordinary provision if I read it correctly. The subparagraph reads:

(3) Where any of the terms of the lease (whether relating to forfeiture or to any other matter) or any other circumstances render it unlikely that the lease will continue beyond a date falling before the expiration of the term of the lease, the lease shall not be treated as having been granted for a term longer than one ending on that date . . .

The question of whether it is unlikely that a lease will continue beyond a particular date is, on the face of it, a most peculiar provision. Here it specifically spells out that it is unlikely because of circumstances relating to forfeiture or any other matter and I am asking the Minister how it is decided in relation to a lease that the terms relating to forfeiture are such that it is unlikely the lease will continue beyond a certain date?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: If the condition under which forfeiture would take place is certain to be fulfilled at a specific time, clearly there would be an identifiable termination point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Will the Minister state what kind of circumstances would produce that situation? The nature of forfeiture is not the ordinary termination of the lease. It is the compulsory termination of the lease by the lessor because of certain circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: If some very onerous imposition is placed on the tenant then it would be improbable that the tenant would continue. If, for instance, the tenant were to apply for permission to rebuild and the permission were given subject to some onerous condition, in such circumstances it might be open to construction that a forfeiture was likely to take place because the onerous condition would be unacceptable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: That raises a few questions but I want to keep to the main one for the moment. Surely, in the circumstances described by the Minister, what would be likely to happen would be that the tenant, finding the terms too onerous, would simply carry on without rebuilding. Why would forfeiture be a likely result in such circumstances?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: There might be a high expenditure bill.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Suppose you had a lease for a certain term or for the life of the lessee, whichever was the earlier, do you judge it then on the health of the lessee as to whether it was likely to determine?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: We are dealing with terms of leases.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: The provision says “or any other circumstances render it unlikely that the lease will continue beyond a date falling before the expiration of the term”. The term can be tied to the life of the lessee and, if it is, then you would have to have a Revenue doctor after the lessee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: If the lease was for a term of 500 years or the life of the lessee——

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: It could be for 50 years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: The use of the word “unlikely” is unlikely, if I may put it that way. Quite apart from that, I am still not clear as to how it could happen that a forfeiture of a lease prior to its termination in the ordinary way was a likely event determining for the purposes of this subparagraph the date on which we calculate the lease will expire, with the results that flow from that. There is a specific mention of forfeiture, and this is what intrigues me, in the subparagraph as one of the matters which could render it unlikely that the lease would continue beyond a certain date. Despite the Minister's suggestion of an example, I do not think that really answers the question, and I would guess that the Minister is himself a little bit puzzled as to why the word “forfeiture” could be deemed to be likely to occur on a particular date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: One might reasonably argue that the words in brackets are, perhaps, unnecessary because they say “whether relating to forfeiture or to any other matter” but forfeiture involves a termination so I suppose to that extent the draftsman considered it would not be inappropriate to put in the word “forfeiture”. I agree it is difficult to give an illustration of specific circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I am wondering why it was mentioned at all. As the Minister says, it is specifically mentioned as distinct from anything else.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: It would not weaken it at all if we simply said for the terms of the lease or any other circumstances which would render it unlikely.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: The Minister can have a look at it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I think he should.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: If I am reading it right “any other circumstances” stands on its own legs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: It does.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: If I have a lease on a certain property and there is a likelihood that the local authority will acquire the land on a certain date there is no uncertainty. What do you do there? Is that not “any other circumstances”? Take, for instance, the famous Bray Road which after 20 years is only maturing now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy is a mind reader. I was thinking of that situation.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I am glad the Minister and I are in such close rapport that we can communicate telepathetically now. If my memory serves me aright, notices were served and dates were even anticipated. It was postponed because of various circumstances and it is only now taking place and has not yet been completed, or anything like it. Would that type of thing be a circumstance that would affect the duration of a lease? Obviously acquisition would extinguish a lease and everything else.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: It is very difficult to judge these cases in advance.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Then why put this in? Why not wait?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Circumstances could arise in which the lease would be clearly not a lease of long duration. Circumstances could change. You must have a provision to deal with circumstances if and when they arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Provided the provisions are workable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: But they are workable.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I hate getting into generalities but I am forced into them here. Is there no possibility of this legislature and the judiciary getting, under the Constitution, a consensus of approach to this type of legislation so that the reasonable thing can be done where the intention is clear and get back to Acts of Parliament which are clear in intent letting, if necessary, the judiciary intervene. Stop the game of Cowboys and Indians which is sure to develop. In fact, it is there already. I fail to see the definiteness of this. I fail to see exactly what the Minister is after in wanting to make sure a long lease will not be granted. What is the objection to a long lease? Why is it so necessary to take the view that a lease must be of the shortest possible duration?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I am sure the Deputy is aware that it would be very simple to dress up a short lease as though it were a long lease.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: What is the advantage?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: That would be, from what the Minister said earlier, to the advantage of the Revenue.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: That is what I cannot understand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: There seems to be more to this than we are aware of.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Whether it is a relief or an additional imposition, all this particular paragraph is doing is stating that the lease will be treated as what it really is as a result of certain circumstances. If it is a short lease it will be treated as a short lease. It is doing the reasonable thing Deputy de Valera says we ought to leave to the courts; it is asserting that if a lease is, in fact, a short one then it should be treated as a short one.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: What is the materiality of the legislation? This sounds to me like what one might call tidy administration and tidy accounting. I wonder, from a practical point of view, what is the importance of it? If I can see it will mean a serious loss of revenue or that it will lead to serious evasion then I might modify my point of view. I cannot see that either of these things will happen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: It is relevant, for instance, to determine, whether or not a lease is a wasting asset. If it is under 50 years then it is a wasting asset and will be treated as provided in paragraph 1 of the Third Schedule.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: If it is not treated as a wasting asset it is to the benefit of the Revenue Commissioners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The whole expenditure would be set off on a long lease.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Did the Minister not tell us that if it is treated as a wasting asset, because it is under 50 years, then the table applies? The table is in fact more advantageous than in the case of a wasting asset, other than a lease of land.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: It is a wasting asset under subparagraph (9) of paragraph 1.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Is the Minister saying that to treat a lease as a long lease is more advantageous from the point of view of the taxpayer than to treat it as a short lease qualifying as a wasting asset?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: That is what this is all about. We are getting somewhere.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Is that really important in the practical case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: From the point of view of the Minister, whether it is to the advantage of the taxpayer or the Revenue Commissioner, surely he is not happy about the use of the word “unlikely”? It says that where any term of the lease or any other circumstances render it unlikely that the lease will continue beyond the day then certain things would follow. Who is to judge whether it is likely or unlikely? Surely this is an impractical provision?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: A judge acting reasonably might come to the decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I suggest that only a judge will be able to decide this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: First of all, the decision will be taken by the Revenue Commissioners. If a person at risk objects it will no doubt be decided elsewhere.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: Dare I again make the point I made earlier? This particular provision could apply to a lot of relatively small interests who would not be prepared to take the risk of seriously disputing the matter. If it was one of those provisions likely to go for the big fellow or anything like that I would be with the Minister. If we pass this I am afraid we are putting ourselves a little bit in the position of the big fellow doing the heavy. I can see the Minister coming back and saying that this device of leases might be used in the bigger interests and why not put an upper limit to cover that or do it differently? I agree with Deputy Colley that the word “unlikely” could possibly operate very unfairly in relation to the smaller interests who would not find it economic to assert their rights, and with the larger interests it is an invitation to litigation and incurring costs for the State.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: There must be a better way of handling it than using the word “unlikely”. Surely the Minister cannot be happy with that word?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I think the word “improbable” might be no better.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: I think it needs redrafting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I believe Deputy de Valera is right. This is going too far and is producing an unworkable provision in order to achieve something which is not of very great importance. I suggest that the Minister think again about the whole idea involved in this subparagraph.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Lawyers can dream up some unlikely situations to get around the provisions of the law.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: We will have a Drug Bill soon but no drugs that I know of will produce the pleasant hallucinations for lawyers that these Bills will.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: It is so uncertain what is visualised here as determining whether a lease will be deemed to be a long lease or a short one and the consequences flowing from that. It is based on whether certain circumstances or certain terms of the lease make it likely or unlikely that the lease will go beyond a certain day. Surely that uncertainty really makes the provision unenforceable? Surely the Minister cannot be happy with that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: As I said, any person who feels aggrieved may get satisfaction by appealing against the decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Even to put oneself in the shoes of the appeals commissioner or the judge, how do you determine a thing like this, it is so uncertain? The best you can do is to go on the balance of probability. That kind of uncertainty in determining tax liability is hardly acceptable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Every day the courts are dealing with the balance of probabilities.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: That is the courts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Dublin Central)
Speaker.P: (Dublin Central): We should try to avoid that if possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: I strongly urge the Minister to look again at the thinking behind that subparagraph.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The thinking behind it is sound. I do not think we can make it any more certain than it is. We have in mind circumstances in which people would be providing alternatives for the duration of a lease, ones spelt out in terms of years other than related to certain circumstances and events and so on.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: He cannot get an exemption until the thing really falls in.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Colley Mr. Colley
Speaker.P: Let us take the worst possible view of the situation. If there are alternatives provided, whichever one is operated for the purposes of the law, he is stuck with that. He cannot be chopping and changing from one possible course to the other, presumably. From the point of view of the Revenue Commissioners presumably what is sought to be prevented is a lease which is really a long one, being dressed up to look like a short one. On a long lease he could deduct the total expense of acquisition whereas on a short lease he could not. I presume that is what is behind this. This subparagraph, as phrased, is making it easier rather than more difficult to do that.

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: We are beginning to lose sight of what the Bill is all about. If it is a question of capital gains why not attach the gain and the reliefs to the actual disposal of the property?
